title: 112_hr2252
content: The Act may be cited as the "Citizens' Self-Defense Act of 2011". The Congress finds that police are not legally liable for failing to protect individual citizens, as courts have ruled that their obligation is to the public in general. For example, in Warren v. District of Columbia Metropolitan Police Department, the court stated that municipalities providing police services do not have a duty to protect individuals. The court in Department, 444 A.2d 1 (D.C. App. 1981) stated that municipalities providing police services have a duty only to the public at large, not to individual community members. Former Florida Attorney General Jim Smith reported that police only responded to 200,000 out of 700,000 calls for help to Dade County authorities. The United States Department of Justice found that in 1989, there were 168,881 crimes of violence for which police had not responded within 1 hour. Additionally, every year, more than 2,400,000 people in the United States use a gun to defend themselves against criminals. Every year, over 2.4 million people in the United States use guns to defend themselves, with 192,000 cases involving women protecting themselves from sexual abuse. 92 percent of these self-defense incidents do not result in any harm. In self-defense incidents involving guns, 92 percent of the time, citizens only brandish their gun or fire a warning shot to scare off attackers. Less than 8 percent of the time, a citizen kills or wounds their attacker. Law-abiding citizens are often prosecuted for using firearms in self-defense. The homeowner in Wilmette, Illinois shot an intruder who entered his house twice, once through the door and the second time with a stolen key. The homeowner confronted the intruder, who then jumped through a window and stole the family's car to go to the hospital. The intruder was charged with residential burglary and possession of a stolen vehicle. The courts have granted immunity to police officers using firearms in duty. Law-abiding citizens using firearms to protect themselves from violent felons should not face lawsuits from the felons. The right to obtain firearms for security and use them in defense of self, family, or home is protected by law. (a) Reaffirmation of Right.--A person not prohibited from receiving a firearm by section 922(g) of title 18, United States Code, shall have the right to obtain firearms for security and to use firearms in self-defense, defense of family against imminent threats, and defense of home during the commission of a felony by another person. (a) A person not prohibited from receiving a firearm by section 922(g) of title 18, United States Code, has the right to obtain firearms for security and use them in self-defense, defense of family against imminent threats, and defense of home during the commission of a felony by another person. The term "firearm" includes a shotgun, rifle, or handgun. If this right is violated, the person can take legal action. (c) Enforcement of Right.-- A person whose right under subsection (a) is violated may bring an action in any United States district court for damages, injunctive relief, and attorney's fees against the United States, any State, or any person. The court may award relief as deemed appropriate, including attorney's fees, in an action brought for damages or injunctive relief under subsection (a). An action must be brought within 5 years of discovering the violation.
